static Input * getInstance ()
 Gets the instance of the Input object.

Detailed Description

Class that handles the input.

This will take care of all the input checking and handling.

Member Function Documentation

Input * Input::getInstance (  )  [static]

Gets the instance of the Input object.

Use this to obtain the instance of the input object for the window.

Returns:
Input* A pointer to the instance of the Input object.

string Input::getJoyInput (  ) 

Gets the value of the joystick input.

Returns the string value of the joystick button or hat direction that was hit at that instant if any.

Returns:
string The string that represents what joystick input was recieved. Will be in the form "Joy# But#" or "Joy# Hat'Dir'". Examples: "Joy3 But1" or "Joy2 HatCENTERED" or "Joy4 HatDOWN".

double Input::getJoystickAxisPos ( int  joystickNum,
int  axisNum 
)

Sees how far in either direction a certain axis on an analog stick is being pressed.

Returns a percentage of how far a certain analog axis is being pressed. The returned value will be between 1.0 and -1.0.

Parameters:
joystickNum Which joystick in question. The analog axis in question. X_AXIS_LEFT means the X axis of the left analog stick. Y_AXIS_RIGHT means the Y axis of the right analog stick. Etc.
Returns:
double The percentage of how far that joystick is being pressed in the given axis. Ranges in between 1.0 and -1.0. 0.0 means it is in the center.

string Input::getKeyInput (  ) 

Gets the value of the buffered keyboard input.

Returns the string value of the key that was pressed in the buffered input. Use this function instead of isKeyDown for things where you just want to know if that key was pressed down at that instant. Such examples might be for typing input or moving through a menu in a game.

Returns:
string The key that was being pressed if any. Empty string returned if no key was pressed.

string Input::getMouseInput (  ) 

Gets the value of the mouse input.

Returns the string value of what mouse buttons were hit or released at that instanct if any.

Returns:
string The string that represents what mouse button was hit or released. Example: "Left Down" means that left mouse click was pressed down. "Right Up" means the right mouse click was just released.

Point Input::getMouseLoc (  ) 

Gets the current point location of the mouse in the coordinate system.

Returns at what specific location the mouse is at in the current coordinate system.

Returns:
Point The Point value of the location of the mouse.

double Input::getMouseXloc (  ) 

Gets the current X location of the mouse in the coordinate system.

Returns at what specific location the mouse is at in the current coordinate system.

Returns:
double The X value of the location of the mouse.

double Input::getMouseXPercentage (  ) 

Gets the percentage of how far the x of the mouse is on the screen.

Returns the percentage of how far right the x of the mouse is on the screen. 0.0 means the mouse is on the far left of the screen. 1.0 means its on the far right. 0.5 means it is in the middle.

Returns:
double The percentage of how far the x of the mouse is on the screen. Ranges from 0.0 to 1.0.

double Input::getMouseXRel (  ) 

Gets the value of how far the mouse moved in the X during the last frame.

Returns how far the mouse moved in the X direction in the last frame. Will be relevant to the coordinate system that is being used at the time.

Returns:
double How far the mouse moved in the X direction during the last frame.

double Input::getMouseYloc (  ) 

Gets the current Y location of the mouse in the coordinate system.

Returns at what specific location the mouse is at in the current coordinate system.

Returns:
double The Y value of the location of the mouse.

double Input::getMouseYPercentage (  ) 

Gets the percentage of how far the y of the mouse is on the screen.

Returns the percentage of how far verticle the y of the mouse is on the screen. 0.0 means the mouse is on the bottom of the screen. 1.0 means its on the top. 0.5 means it is in the middle.

Returns:
double The percentage of how far the y of the mouse is on the screen. Ranges from 0.0 to 1.0.

double Input::getMouseYRel (  ) 

Gets the value of how far the mouse moved in the Y during the last frame.

Returns how far the mouse moved in the Y direction in the last frame. Will be relevant to the coordinate system that is being used at the time.

Returns:
double How far the mouse moved in the Y direction during the last frame.

bool Input::handleEvents (  ) 

Will handle all events that have occured.

Will handle all of the events that have occured since last calling this function. This must be called to ensure that tracking of the mouse pointer is done as well as recieving all of the buffered keyboard input. If false has been returned, then the program has been asked to be quit.

Returns:
bool True means the program is doing fine and false means the program has been asked to be quit. If false was returned, the programmer must quit the program to ensure that the program quits when asked to.

bool Input::isHatDirPressed ( string  joyHatDir  ) 

Checks to see if a hat direction is being pressed.

Returns whether or not a certain direction on the hat is down.

Parameters:
joyHatDir The hat direction in question. Must be in the format "Joy# Hat'Dir'". So "Joy2 HatLEFT" is asking whether or not the left direction is being pressed on the hat of joystick 2.
Returns:
bool Whether or not that hat direction is being pressed.

bool Input::isJoyButtonDown ( string  joyButton  ) 

Checks to see if a certain joystick button is pressed.

Returns whether or not a certain joystick button is down.

Parameters:
joyButton The joystick button in question. Must be in the format "Joy# But#". So "Joy0 But5" is asking whether or not button 5 on joystick 0 is being pressed.
Returns:
bool Whether or not that button was down.

bool Input::isKeyDown ( string  key  ) 

Checks to see if a keyboard key is pressed.

Will return whether or not a certain key is being pressed.

Parameters:
key The string value of the key in question. Example: "a" => A key, "esc" => esc key, "space" => space key
Returns:
bool Whether or not the key in question is pressed.

bool Input::leftMouseDown (  ) 

Whether or not the left mouse button is down.

Will return whether or not the left mouse button is currently being pressed.

Returns:
bool Whether or not it is being pressed.

void Input::release (  ) 

Releases the instance of the Input object obtained.

Release the instance of the Input obtained from getInstance(). This must be called on the pointer obtained from getInstance() to ensure that no memory leaks occur and that the Input object is destroyed when nobody has an instance of the object.

void Input::resetInput (  ) 

Clears all the values in the input variables.

Will reset all of the calculated inputs in handleEvents back to cleared. This must be called at the end of the simulation loop to make sure that a certain input is not seen to have been pressed when actually it was pressed along time ago in the passed.

bool Input::rightMouseDown (  ) 

Whether or not the right mose button is down.

Will return whether or not the right mouse button is currently being pressed.

Returns:
bool Whether or not it is being pressed.

void Input::setMouseX ( double  mouseX  ) 

Sets the x mouse coordinate to the given value.

This should not be used by the programmer. This is specifically used by the input class and window class when changing coordinate systems.

Parameters:
mouseX The new x mouse location.

void Input::setMouseY ( double  mouseY  ) 

Sets the y mouse coordinate to the given value.

This should not be used by the programmer. This is specifically used by the input class and window class when changing coordinate systems.

Parameters:
mouseY The new y mouse location.
